Throughout these lectures, we have been considering the
analysis and the implementation

of discrete time linear
shift invariant systems, or what we've been referring
to as digital filters.

In this lecture, I
would like to begin the discussion of the
design of digital filters.

Now the rationale
for digital filters is exactly the same as
it is for analog filters.

In particular, we have taken
advantage several times of the important
property of linear shift

in variance systems that complex

added when these signals occupy

different frequency bands. Specifically, we can
consider a signal composed

of the sum of two signals,
one of which we want, the other of which
we don't want,

or we would like to suppress. And if those two signals are
in different frequency bands--

in other words, their spectra
occupy different segments

of the frequency axis, then we
can choose the system function

for the linear shift
invariant system so that it is unity in
the band of frequencies

that we want to keep and at
0 in the band of frequencies that we want to reject.

That of course, is
exactly the same notion as we have in continuous time
or analog systems or filters.

So for example, if we
had a signal, which was the sum of two components,
one of which was low frequency,

and that we wanted to keep,
and the other of which was high frequency and
that we wanted to suppress,

frequency response ideally

high frequency end,

piecewise constant as they

constant such as, for example,

characteristic is

in fact, linear with frequency,

frequency characteristic is

in general of a somewhat
arbitrary shape. And so in this

the implementation

invariant system with a specified frequency
response characteristic

I'll relate primarily to
